content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with service in the armed forces and exposure to biological, chemical, or other toxic agents under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for Project 112. The new section added to title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, specifically for diagnosed diseases linked to increased exposure to toxic agents during military service. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, specifically for diagnosed diseases linked to increased exposure to toxic agents during military service. Veterans who served on active duty and were subjected to chemical or biological warfare tests under Project 112 and have a disease described in the regulations shall be presumed to have been exposed to a toxic agent associated with the disease unless there is conclusive evidence otherwise. The Secretary shall prescribe regulations for a presumption of service connection for diseases linked to exposure to toxic agents during military service under Project 112, based on sound medical evidence. Sound medical and scientific information will be considered in making these determinations. The Secretary will consider all relevant medical and scientific information when evaluating reports for determining associations between diseases and exposure to toxic agents. An association will be deemed positive if credible evidence supports it. Removal of the presumption of service connection for a disease will not affect compensation for veterans or their survivors previously awarded based on that presumption. Project 112 is defined as the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses related to chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must create regulations within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must provide all records of exposed personnel within 30 days. A report on Project 112, including costs, benefits, and participant information, must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. Project 112, a chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD, requires a full accounting of participant information and addresses concerns held by the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations.
